elements.content: Actinide-based metal–organic materials have drawn much attention due to their intriguing 5f bonding properties and promising applications in nuclear fuels and other fields. Introduction of weak interactions, such as halogen bonds, into actinide–organic hybrid materials will provide them with more flexibility and dynamics. The first case of halogen bonded three-dimensional (3D) uranyl–organic supramolecular frameworks with regular nanoscale channels has been obtained from multifunctional halogen-substituted isonicotinic acids. Distinct from conventional halogen bonded uranyl–organic frameworks, the supramolecular networks obtained here consist of three-component cocrystals and have been assemblied by intensive supramolecular networks to obtain an extended 3D geometry. Moreover, secondary “X3” and “X6” halogen–halogen interactions resulting from the driving forces of primary hydrogen bonds have been found and analyzed by quantum chemical calculation, indicating their feature of weak bonding and special geometry. It is notable that this unprecedented type of “X6” synthon, especially for “Br6”, represents a new pattern of halogen–halogen interaction. When halogen substitution of the organic precursor is changed, another type of halogen bonded and hydrogen bonded 3D uranyl–organic framework with two-dimensional layered networks and cross-linking agents formed in situ was acquired. Finally, reversible transformation of 3D uranyl–organic supramolecular frameworks is available through loss and regain of water involving in hydrogen bonding networks and thus affords them structural dynamics.

Moreover, secondary "X3" and "X6" halogen-halogen interactions resulting from the driving forces of primary hydrogen bonds have been found and analyzed by quantum chemical calculation, indicating their feature of weak bonding and special geometry. When halogen substitution of the organic precursor is changed, another type of halogen bonded and hydrogen bonded 3D uranyl-organic framework with two-dimensional layered networks and cross-linking agents formed in situ was acquired. Finally, reversible transformation of 3D uranyl-organic supramolecular frameworks is available through loss and regain of water involving in hydrogen bonding networks and thus affords them structural dynamics.

elements.content: Halogen bonded three-dimensional uranyl−organic supramolecular frameworks with regular nanoscale channels have been assemblied by a cooperation of halogen−halogen interactions and hydrogen bonds as well as secondary “X3” and “X6” halogen−halogen interactions from the precursors of 2,6-dihalogenisonicotinc acid, and structure diversity could be achieved by variation of halogen substitution to the 3,5-positon.

elements.content: Metal–organic materials, which show potential applications in a wide range of fields including adsorption, separation, recognition, and catalysis, are usually established by strong coordination bonds between metal ions and rigid organic molecules. Introduction of flexibility and dynamism into metal–organic materials will extend topologies and functions of metal–organic materials. A strategy of using weak interactions as auxiliary linkage forces has been proven successful. Besides the wide application of the hydrogen bond as a weak interaction in metal–organic hybrid materials, a variety of metal–organic materials incorporating halogen bond have also been obtained. The halogen bond, an important bonding force comparable to hydrogen bonding, has been used in crystal engineering for many supramolecular systems, establishing lots of compounds with fascinating structures and outstanding properties.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Metal-organic materials, which show potential applications in a wide range of fields including adsorption, separation, recognition, and catalysis, are usually established by strong coordination bonds between metal ions and rigid organic molecules. Introduction of flexibility and dynamism into metal-organic materials will extend topologies and functions of metal-organic materials. A strategy of using weak interactions as auxiliary linkage forces has been proven successful. Besides the wide application of the hydrogen bond as a weak interaction in metal-organic hybrid materials, a variety of metal-organic materials incorporating halogen bond have also been obtained. The halogen bond, an important bonding force comparable to hydrogen bonding, has been used in crystal engineering for many supramolecular systems, establishing lots of compounds with fascinating structures and outstanding properties.

elements.content: In contrast to the large amount of transition metal organic supramolecular materials, actinide ions that bear intriguing 5f bonding properties and various topologies have been less investigated in the field of metal–organic supramolecular materials. For example, for uranium, one of the most studied actinide elements in relation to its structure diversities and close relevance to nuclear fuel cycle, much attention has been focused on extended uranyl–organic materials, whereas endeavors on weak interactions-related uranyl–organic compounds are relatively lacking. Moreover, compared with hydrogen bonds appearing more commonly in metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) (such as uranyl isonicotinate), the utilization of halogen bonds is still in its infancy in terms of establishing uranyl–organic compounds. Incorporation of halogen bonds in uranyl–organic materials will not only enrich the library of uranyl-organic compounds based on weak interaction and provide novel uranyl hybrid supramolecular materials, but also, to a certain extent, promote a deeper understanding of the halogen bond. Constructing halogen bonded uranyl–organic compounds, especially those in three dimensions, will be an interesting arena for metal organic materials to explore structures with flexibility. To the best of our knowledge, however, a halogen bond-based three-dimensional (3D) uranyl–organic framework has never been documented to date possibly due to low participation of weak interactions as well as restricted coordination geometry of the uranyl ion. In the light of the methodology of building MOFs, a possible approach to construct 3D supramolecular frameworks is the employment of organic ligands with multidentate bonding sites for weak interactions.
elements.clean_text: In contrast to the large amount of transition metal organic supramolecular materials, actinide ions that bear intriguing 5f bonding properties and various topologies have been less investigated in the field of metal-organic supramolecular materials. For example, for uranium, one of the most studied actinide elements in relation to its structure diversities and close relevance to nuclear fuel cycle, much attention has been focused on extended uranyl-organic materials, whereas endeavors on weak interactions-related uranyl-organic compounds are relatively lacking. Moreover, compared with hydrogen bonds appearing more commonly in metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) (such as uranyl isonicotinate), the utilization of halogen bonds is still in its infancy in terms of establishing uranyl-organic compounds. Incorporation of halogen bonds in uranyl-organic materials will not only enrich the library of uranyl-organic compounds based on weak interaction and provide novel uranyl hybrid supramolecular materials, but also, to a certain extent, promote a deeper understanding of the halogen bond. Constructing halogen bonded uranyl-organic compounds, especially those in three dimensions, will be an interesting arena for metal organic materials to explore structures with flexibility. To the best of our knowledge, however, a halogen bond-based three-dimensional (3D) uranyl-organic framework has never been documented to date possibly due to low participation of weak interactions as well as restricted coordination geometry of the uranyl ion. In the light of the methodology of building MOFs, a possible approach to construct 3D supramolecular frameworks is the employment of organic ligands with multidentate bonding sites for weak interactions.

elements.content: In this context, we explore the cooperation of halogen bonds and hydrogen bonds to construct 3D uranyl–organic supramolecular frameworks using multifunctional ligands, halogen-substituted isonicotinic acids (Scheme ). As the building scaffold of uranyl–organic supramolecular frameworks, the isonicotinic acid moiety in the molecular structures of halogen-substituted isonicotinic acids serves as the coordination precursor for uranyl ions and contributor of hydrogen bonds, and halogen atoms as the contributors of halogen bonds. Herein, the first case of halogen bonded 3D uranyl–organic supramolecular frameworks with regular nanoscale channels has been obtained. Notably, both the supramolecular networks have been constructed by three different components in their cocrystal structure via cooperation of halogen–halogen interactions and hydrogen bonds as well as secondary “X3” and “X6” (X = Cl, Br) halogen–halogen interactions. As far as we know, this unprecedented type of “X6” synthon is reported for the first time and represents a new pattern of halogen–halogen interaction, especially for the “Br6” synthon. Furthermore, structure diversity of uranyl isonicotinate compounds has been identified when the halogen-substitution is varied, and another type of 3D supramolecular uranyl–organic framework with two-dimensional (2D) layered networks has been obtained.
elements.clean_text: In this context, we explore the cooperation of halogen bonds and hydrogen bonds to construct 3D uranyl-organic supramolecular frameworks using multifunctional ligands, halogen-substituted isonicotinic acids (Scheme ). As the building scaffold of uranyl-organic supramolecular frameworks, the isonicotinic acid moiety in the molecular structures of halogen-substituted isonicotinic acids serves as the coordination precursor for uranyl ions and contributor of hydrogen bonds, and halogen atoms as the contributors of halogen bonds. Herein, the first case of halogen bonded 3D uranyl-organic supramolecular frameworks with regular nanoscale channels has been obtained. Notably, both the supramolecular networks have been constructed by three different components in their cocrystal structure via cooperation of halogen-halogen interactions and hydrogen bonds as well as secondary "X3" and "X6" (X = Cl, Br) halogen-halogen interactions. As far as we know, this unprecedented type of "X6" synthon is reported for the first time and represents a new pattern of halogen-halogen interaction, especially for the "Br6" synthon. Furthermore, structure diversity of uranyl isonicotinate compounds has been identified when the halogen-substitution is varied, and another type of 3D supramolecular uranyl-organic framework with two-dimensional (2D) layered networks has been obtained.

elements.content: Caution! Suitable precautionary measures and protection should be taken, and all operations should follow the criteria while handling such substances although natural uranium was used in the experiment. All chemical reagents were purchased from commercial sources and used as received. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was performed on a TA Q500 analyzer over the temperature range of 20–800 °C in air atmosphere with a heating rate of 5 °C/min. Powder XRD measurements were recorded on a Bruker D8 Advance diffractometer with Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.5406 Å) in the range 5–80°(step size: 0.02°). Solid-state fluorescence spectra were measured on a Hitachi F-4600 fluorescence spectrophotometer. Electrospray ionization mass spectrometry (ESI-MS) spectra were obtained with a Bruker AmaZon SL ion trap mass spectrometer (Bruker, USA). The Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR) spectra were recorded from KBr pellets in the range of 4000–400 cm–1 on at Bruker Tensor 27 spectrometer.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

General Methods

Caution! Suitable precautionary measures and protection should be taken, and all operations should follow the criteria while handling such substances although natural uranium was used in the experiment. All chemical reagents were purchased from commercial sources and used as received. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was performed on a TA Q500 analyzer over the temperature range of 20-800 °C in air atmosphere with a heating rate of 5 °C/min. Powder XRD measurements were recorded on a Bruker D8 Advance diffractometer with Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.5406 Å) in the range 5-80°(step size: 0.02°). Solid-state fluorescence spectra were measured on a Hitachi F-4600 fluorescence spectrophotometer. Electrospray ionization mass spectrometry (ESI-MS) spectra were obtained with a Bruker AmaZon SL ion trap mass spectrometer (Bruker, USA). The Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR) spectra were recorded from KBr pellets in the range of 4000-400 cm-1 on at Bruker Tensor 27 spectrometer.

elements.content: The compounds 1–4 described herein were synthesized hydrothermally as the forms of yellow-green or yellow crystals under autogenous pressure by using a Teflon-lined stainless-steel bomb from a mixture of uranyl nitrate hexahydrate and isonicotinic acid derivatives (L1–L4) with ammonium hydroxide. A typical synthesis precedure is as follows: UO2(NO3)2­·6H2O (200 μL, 0.1 mmol) were added to a suspension of isonicotinic acid precucusor (0.2 mmol) in water (1 mL) in a stainless-steel bomb. After treating with ammonium hydroxide (10 μL), the mixture was sealed, kept at 150 °C for 48 h, and cooled to room temperature to give yellow-green prism-like crystals, which were suitable for X-ray single crystal diffraction. The crystals were then filtered off, washed with water, and dried at room temperature (RT).
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis

The compounds 1-4 described herein were synthesized hydrothermally as the forms of yellow-green or yellow crystals under autogenous pressure by using a Teflon-lined stainless-steel bomb from a mixture of uranyl nitrate hexahydrate and isonicotinic acid derivatives (L1-L4) with ammonium hydroxide. A typical synthesis precedure is as follows: UO2(NO3)2⋅6H2O (200 μL, 0.1 mmol) were added to a suspension of isonicotinic acid precucusor (0.2 mmol) in water (1 mL) in a stainless-steel bomb. After treating with ammonium hydroxide (10 μL), the mixture was sealed, kept at 150 °C for 48 h, and cooled to room temperature to give yellow-green prism-like crystals, which were suitable for X-ray single crystal diffraction. The crystals were then filtered off, washed with water, and dried at room temperature (RT).

elements.content: The hydrothermal reaction of monochloro-substituted ligands, L1′ or L1″, with uranyl nitrate hexahydrate was performed under conditions similar for compounds 1–4 to afford yellow crystals (compound 1′) or brown crystals (compound 1″). Moreover, a different reaction temperature or time was set systematically to explore the methods of avoiding the hydrolysis of the chloro-substituent group.
elements.clean_text: The hydrothermal reaction of monochloro-substituted ligands, L1' or L1", with uranyl nitrate hexahydrate was performed under conditions similar for compounds 1-4 to afford yellow crystals (compound 1') or brown crystals (compound 1"). Moreover, a different reaction temperature or time was set systematically to explore the methods of avoiding the hydrolysis of the chloro-substituent group.

elements.content: X-ray diffraction data were all collected on a Agilent SuperNova X-ray CCD diffractometer with a Mo Kα X-ray source (λ = 0.71073 Å) or Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.5406 Å) at room temperature. Standard Agilent Crysalis software was used for the determination of the unit cells and data collection control. The crystal structures were solved by means of direct methods and refined with full-matrix least-squares on SHELXL-97. The crystal data are given in Table . CCDC-1006404 (1), CCDC-1006405 (2), CCDC-1010189 (1′), CCDC-1010190 (1″), CCDC-1010191 (L1″, H-2-MC-6-MePCA), CCDC-1026410 (L3, H-3,5-DCPCA), CCDC-1026411 (3), CCDC-1026412 (4), contain the supplementary crystallographic data for this paper. These data can be obtained free of charge from The Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre via www.ccdc.cam.ac.uk/data_request/cif.

X-ray Single Crystal Structural Determination

X-ray diffraction data were all collected on a Agilent SuperNova X-ray CCD diffractometer with a Mo Kα X-ray source (λ = 0.71073 Å) or Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.5406 Å) at room temperature. Standard Agilent Crysalis software was used for the determination of the unit cells and data collection control. The crystal structures were solved by means of direct methods and refined with full-matrix least-squares on SHELXL-97. The crystal data are given in Table . CCDC-1006404 (1), CCDC-1006405 (2), CCDC-1010189 (1'), CCDC-1010190 (1"), CCDC-1010191 (L1", H-2-MC-6-MePCA), CCDC-1026410 (L3, H-3,5-DCPCA), CCDC-1026411 (3), CCDC-1026412 (4), contain the supplementary crystallographic data for this paper. These data can be obtained free of charge from The Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre via www.ccdc.cam.ac.uk/data_request/cif.

In density functional theory (DFT) calculations, scalar relativistic effects were taken into account by the quasi-relativistic effective core potentials (RECP) including 60 core electrons and the corresponding valence basis sets for uranium. The 6-31G(d) basis sets were adopted for light atoms H, C, N, O, Cl, and Br. No symmetry constraints were used for geometry optimization. The minima character of each optimized structure was verified by harmonic vibrational frequency analysis at the B3LYP/RECP/6-31G(d) level of theory. Previous studies have been found that this level of theory could provide accurate geometries for actinide species. All these calculations were performed with the Gaussian 09 program package.
elements.clean_text:
Quantum Chemical Calculation for Structure Optimization and Quantum Theory of Atoms in Molecules (QTAIM) Analysis

In density functional theory (DFT) calculations, scalar relativistic effects were taken into account by the quasi-relativistic effective core potentials (RECP) including 60 core electrons and the corresponding valence basis sets for uranium. The 6-31G(d) basis sets were adopted for light atoms H, C, N, O, Cl, and Br. No symmetry constraints were used for geometry optimization. The minima character of each optimized structure was verified by harmonic vibrational frequency analysis at the B3LYP/RECP/6-31G(d) level of theory. Previous studies have been found that this level of theory could provide accurate geometries for actinide species. All these calculations were performed with the Gaussian 09 program package.

elements.content: For the analysis of “X3” and “X6” synthons, DFT calculations using the Gaussian 09 package were carried out for the model fragments of 1 and 2 using the M06-2X functional. Previous studies have shown that the M06-2X method could give good results for complexes with noncovalent interactions. It has been found that diffuse functions are important to obtain considerably better results for weakly bound systems. The 6-311+G(d, p) basis sets were adopted for light atoms H, C, N, O, Cl, and Br, while for uranium the same basis set as used for structure optimization is also used here. Single point calculations have been carried out at the M06-2X/RECP/6-311+G(d, p) level of theory based on the model fragments from the experimental crystal structures of 1 and 2. At the same level of theory, the quantum theory of atoms in molecules (QTAIM) analysis has been carried out with the Multiwfn 3.3.3 package.

elements.content: Compound 1, prepared from 2,6-dichloroisonicotinic acid (H-2,6-DCPCA, L1, see Scheme ), crystallizes in the triclinic space group P1̅ as a cocrystal. It contains three components, which are te dimeric uranium unit, free H-2,6-DCPCA molecules, and solvate water molecules (Figure ), respectively. The dimeric uranium unit is composed of two monomeric uranyl cations bridged through the μ2-(O,O)-carboxylic acid groups, and each uranyl further coordinates with a water molecule and a η2-mode carboxylic group to form a pentagonal bipyramid geometry with equatorial U–O distances from 2.316(4) to 2.469(4) Å (Figure and Table ). Though the dimeric uranyl coordination pattern is similar to that observed in the uranyl complexes of 4-halobenzoic acids, the overall configurations of dimer in 1 are quite different: the H-2,6-DCPCA ligand prefers good coplanarity, while the 4-halobenzoic acid results in a bend out of plane. DFT calculations were carried out to optimize the geometrical structure of the dimer (see the , Figure S1a), and the result is in good accordance with the experimental structure in crystal (), indicating a different coordination feature of 2,6-DCPCA from simple halogen-substituted benzoic acid.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Structure Description

[(UO2)2(2,6-DCPCA)4(H2O)2]⋅(H-2,6-DCPCA)2⋅(H2O)2 (1)

Compound 1, prepared from 2,6-dichloroisonicotinic acid (H-2,6-DCPCA, L1, see Scheme ), crystallizes in the triclinic space group P1̅ as a cocrystal. It contains three components, which are te dimeric uranium unit, free H-2,6-DCPCA molecules, and solvate water molecules (Figure ), respectively. The dimeric uranium unit is composed of two monomeric uranyl cations bridged through the μ2-(O,O)-carboxylic acid groups, and each uranyl further coordinates with a water molecule and a η2-mode carboxylic group to form a pentagonal bipyramid geometry with equatorial U-O distances from 2.316(4) to 2.469(4) Å (Figure  and Table ). Though the dimeric uranyl coordination pattern is similar to that observed in the uranyl complexes of 4-halobenzoic acids, the overall configurations of dimer in 1 are quite different: the H-2,6-DCPCA ligand prefers good coplanarity, while the 4-halobenzoic acid results in a bend out of plane. DFT calculations were carried out to optimize the geometrical structure of the dimer (see the , Figure S1a), and the result is in good accordance with the experimental structure in crystal (), indicating a different coordination feature of 2,6-DCPCA from simple halogen-substituted benzoic acid.

elements.content: Asymmetric unit of 1 containing three components and coordination sphere of dimeric uranium unit.

On the basis of the coplanar configuration, the outward halogen atoms in each dimer associate with adjacent dimers by ditopic halogen–halogen interactions to obtain an extended one-dimensional (1D) chain (Figure a). The Cl–Cl distance of 3.416(3) Å is shorter than the sum of van der Waals radii (ca. 3.6 Å), and the C–Cl···Cl angles (θ1 and θ2) of 170.26(21)° and 161.02(20)° are approximately equal, indicating that the halogen–halogen interaction is of type I. Besides the uranyl dimer in cocrystal 1, another two components, noncoordinated H-2,6-DCPCA and water molecules, are included, which insert into the voids of adjacent 1D chains of uranyl dimers to build up a 3D uranyl–organic supramolecular framework with two types of regular nanoscale channels in sizes of 10.5*5.5 Å and 14.0*4.0 Å by hydrogen bonds and halogen bonds (Figure b).

elements.content: A local stacking model containing two H-2,6-DCPCA and two water molecules (bolded, facing down and up) filling in a typical cavity around four adjacent uranyl dimers (Figure ) is subtly selected, and a structural analysis is made in detail to figure out how the hydrogen bonds and halogen bonds work. It was noticed that all the carboxylic acids filling into the voids incline from the 1D halogen–halogen bonded chains with an angle of ca. 47.65°. As shown in Figure , the H-2,6-DCPCA facing down interacts with O(5)–H(5A) belonging to the coordinated H2O of a uranyl dimer nearby in layer B through the N(3) atom. From the opposite direction, it hydrogen bonds to the free water (O(1w)) by the carboxylic acid group and subsequently links to another two neighboring dimers (in layers A and B) via O(1w)–H···N(1) and O(1w)–H···O(6) hydrogen bonding. Moreover, another two C–H···O hydrogen bonds, C(9)–H···O(6) and C(12)–H···O(1), increase the complexity of the hydrogen-bond networks. Similarly, the other H-2,6-DCPCA in the same cavity, which faces up, interacts with the neighboring chains of uranyl dimers by hydrogen-bond networks from an inverse direction.

Moreover, another two C-H⋅⋅⋅O hydrogen bonds, C(9)-H⋅⋅⋅O(6) and C(12)-H⋅⋅⋅O(1), increase the complexity of the hydrogen-bond networks. elements.content: Further analysis of the packing mode of these inserted H-2,6-DCPCA molecules reveals an interesting phenomenon: besides extensive participation in hydrogen bonding, both the halogen atoms of each H-2,6-DCPCA molecule also locate precisely near the halogen atoms of uranyl dimers in different layers to form a asymmetric triangular “Cl3” with three vertical angles of 63.65(5)°, 68.41(5)°, and 47.94(4)° and a centrosymmetric hexagonal cyclic “Cl6” synthon bearing three different angles of 139.41(6)°, 144.99(6)°, and 72.30(5)°, respectively (Figure a). Although the “Cl3” synthon is commonly observed in many systems of halogen organic derivatives, as far as we know, this unprecedented “Cl6” synthon here is observed for the first time, which represents a new type of halogen–halogen interaction. This special location of H-2,6-DCPCA molecule results in cross-linking by an intrasheet “Cl3” synthon and intersheet “Cl6” synthon in one layer of uranyl sheets (Figure b). Compared to the distance of ditopic Cl–Cl interaction, the newly built edge lengths in “Cl3” synthon are slightly longer (Table ), while those in the “Cl6” synthon with the shortest distance of 3.668(3) Å are closer to the sum of the van der Waals radii. Moreover, the C–Cl···Cl angles for the “Cl3” and “Cl6” synthons are different from those observed in type I or type II halogen–halogen interactions. On the basis of the longer distances of Cl–Cl as well as anomalous C–X···X angles, these two types of bonds created by inserted H-2,6-DCPCA should be a secondary interaction resulting from the driving forces of primary hydrogen bonds.

Reaction of uranyl nitrate hexahydrate with 2-chloroisonicotinic acid (H-2-MCPCA, L1′) under hydrothermal conditions similar to 1 affords the uranyl compound 1′. The structure of compound 1′ is composed of a uranyl center in pentagonal bipyramid geometry, which is coordinated to a η2–carboxyl group, a η1-carboxyl group, and two hydroxyl groups from four 2-hydroxyisonicotinate (2-MHPCA) motifs to form a 2D wave-shaped network with intrasheet hydrogen bonds (). It is interesting to note that there is no chlorine atom in the structure of compound 1′, and instead, a hydroxyl oxygen atom takes the place of chlorine, indicating the hydrolysis of chlorine under hydrothermal conditions may produce a 2-MHPCA molecule as a real ligand of uranyl cation. This phenomenon of hydrolysis is further proved by a minor amount of colorless needle-like crystals in the hydrothermal product, which gives the MS peak (m/z) of 139.87 in ESI-MS, corresponding to the molecular ionic peak of hydrolyzed ligand ([C6H5NO3 + H]+). Besides, the loss of fluorescence is further evidence of the adduction of hydroxyl groups resulting from the hydrolysis of chlorine, as the coordination of a hydroxyl group to the uranyl cation could quench the fluorescence through a nonradiative decay mechanism induced by the oscillation of OH bonds (see the , Figure S7). Moreover, only one obvious weight loss in thermogravimetric analysis indicates its good structural stability based on 2D coordination networks, which should be in close relation to the cross-linking capacity of hydroxyl groups ().

UO2(2-MHPCA)2 (1')

It is interesting to note that there is no chlorine atom in the structure of compound 1', and instead, a hydroxyl oxygen atom takes the place of chlorine, indicating the hydrolysis of chlorine under hydrothermal conditions may produce a 2-MHPCA molecule as a real ligand of uranyl cation. This phenomenon of hydrolysis is further proved by a minor amount of colorless needle-like crystals in the hydrothermal product, which gives the MS peak (m/z) of 139.87 in ESI-MS, corresponding to the molecular ionic peak of hydrolyzed ligand ([C6H5NO3 + H]+). Besides, the loss of fluorescence is further evidence of the adduction of hydroxyl groups resulting from the hydrolysis of chlorine, as the coordination of a hydroxyl group to the uranyl cation could quench the fluorescence through a nonradiative decay mechanism induced by the oscillation of OH bonds (see the , Figure S7). elements.content: When another analogue of H-2,6-DCPCA, named 2-chloro-6-methylisonicotinic acid (H-2-MC-6-MePCA, L1″), was used to react with uranyl nitrate under similar hydrothermal conditions, compound l″ was obtained. In the crystal structure of 1″, the chlorine-substituted H-2-MC-6-MePCA precursor can also undergo a hydrolysis into 2-hydroxy-6-methylisonicotinate (2-MH-6-MePCA), and even another oxalate (ox) ligand formed in situ can be found (). The oxalate ligand takes part in the coordination of uranyl cation in a bridging pattern to form a uranyl dimer, which further interconnects each other through the bidentate 2-MH-6-MePCA to obtain a 1D extended chain () with intrachain hydrogen bonds between adjacent dimers (O(4)–H(4B)···O(8), ) for structure stabilization. Moreover, the 1D extended chain can be weaved into a 3D network via two types of interchain hydrogen bonds as well as π–π stacking ().

[UO2(2-MH-6-MePCA)(H2O)(ox)0.5]⋅(H2O)2 (1")

When another analogue of H-2,6-DCPCA, named 2-chloro-6-methylisonicotinic acid (H-2-MC-6-MePCA, L1"), was used to react with uranyl nitrate under similar hydrothermal conditions, compound l" was obtained. In the crystal structure of 1", the chlorine-substituted H-2-MC-6-MePCA precursor can also undergo a hydrolysis into 2-hydroxy-6-methylisonicotinate (2-MH-6-MePCA), and even another oxalate (ox) ligand formed in situ can be found (). The oxalate ligand takes part in the coordination of uranyl cation in a bridging pattern to form a uranyl dimer, which further interconnects each other through the bidentate 2-MH-6-MePCA to obtain a 1D extended chain () with intrachain hydrogen bonds between adjacent dimers (O(4)-H(4B)⋅⋅⋅O(8), ) for structure stabilization. Moreover, the 1D extended chain can be weaved into a 3D network via two types of interchain hydrogen bonds as well as π-π stacking ().

elements.content: Compound 2 affords a similar cocrystal structure (Figure a) using 2,6-dibromoisonicotinic acid (H-2,6-DBPCA, L2) as the hydrothermal reaction precursor. The carboxyl-bridged uranyl dimer species with typical equatorial U–O distances from 2.314(4) to 2.464(4) Å also show good coplanarity (Figure a and ) and mutually linked with adjacent units to form an extended 1D chain by halogen–halogen interactions of type I, where the Br–Br distance is 3.406 Å, and the approximately equal C–X···X angles are 156.60° and 168.40°. It is notable that the shortening of Br–Br distance (∼0.40 Å) compared with the sum of the van der Waals radii in compound 2 is greater than that of the Cl–Cl distance (∼0.18 Å) in compound 1, suggesting stronger halogen–halogen interaction for this bromide analogue.
elements.clean_text:
[(UO2)2(2,6-DBPCA)4(H2O)2]⋅(H-2,6-DBPCA)2⋅(H2O)2 (2)

Compound 2 affords a similar cocrystal structure (Figure a) using 2,6-dibromoisonicotinic acid (H-2,6-DBPCA, L2) as the hydrothermal reaction precursor. The carboxyl-bridged uranyl dimer species with typical equatorial U-O distances from 2.314(4) to 2.464(4) Å also show good coplanarity (Figure a and ) and mutually linked with adjacent units to form an extended 1D chain by halogen-halogen interactions of type I, where the Br-Br distance is 3.406 Å, and the approximately equal C-X⋅⋅⋅X angles are 156.60° and 168.40°. It is notable that the shortening of Br-Br distance (~0.40 Å) compared with the sum of the van der Waals radii in compound 2 is greater than that of the Cl-Cl distance (~0.18 Å) in compound 1, suggesting stronger halogen-halogen interaction for this bromide analogue.

elements.content: As expected similar to 1, free carboxylic acid and water molecules cross-link the 1D chains of uranyl dimers by hydrogen bonds and halogen bonds to make out a 3D framework with regular nanoscale channels (10.8*5.5 Å and 14.2*4.1 Å) (Figure ). The inclined angle of 51.65° between the inserted carboxylic acid and the 1D chains is slightly different to that in 1. A criss-crossed hydrogen-bond network as well as unique triangular “Br3” and hexagonal cyclic “Br6” joints are responsible for the construction of the 3D supramolecular framework. Again, a stronger halogen–halogen interaction for the bromide analogue is observed as indicated by the smaller difference of Br–Br distances from the sum of the van der Waals radii in “Br3” or “Br6” joints than those in “Cl3” and “Cl6” joints (Table ).

The inclined angle of 51.65° between the inserted carboxylic acid and the 1D chains is slightly different to that in 1. A criss-crossed hydrogen-bond network as well as unique triangular "Br3" and hexagonal cyclic "Br6" joints are responsible for the construction of the 3D supramolecular framework. Again, a stronger halogen-halogen interaction for the bromide analogue is observed as indicated by the smaller difference of Br-Br distances from the sum of the van der Waals radii in "Br3" or "Br6" joints than those in "Cl3" and "Cl6" joints (Table ).

elements.content: Compound 3 was prepared from 3,5-dichloroisonicotinic acid (H-3,5-DCPCA, L3), a position isomer of H-2,6-DCPCA. Two independent components, which are the uranyl–organic moiety and 3,5-dichloropyridinium, are included in compound 3 (Figure a). In the uranyl–organic moiety, the uranyl cation exhibits a pentagonal bipyramid geometry with an equatorial plane in a “NO4“ coordination pattern, which contains not only the carboxyl group but also the nitrogen atom in the pyridine ring of 3,5-DCPCA (Figure b). Another two coordinated oxygen atoms in the equatorial plane serve as corner-sharing atoms to interconnect the adjacent uranyl polyhedral in the trans position, resulting in an infinite chain. The 1D chain of multi-nuclear uranyl further extends to a 2D layered network through the connection of the bidentate 3,5-DCPCA linkers (Figure c).

In the uranyl-organic moiety, the uranyl cation exhibits a pentagonal bipyramid geometry with an equatorial plane in a "NO4" coordination pattern, which contains not only the carboxyl group but also the nitrogen atom in the pyridine ring of 3,5-DCPCA (Figure b). Another two coordinated oxygen atoms in the equatorial plane serve as corner-sharing atoms to interconnect the adjacent uranyl polyhedral in the trans position, resulting in an infinite chain. elements.content: Besides the uranyl-involving moiety, the other part in the structure of 3 is 3,5-dichloropyridinium, which results from in situ decarboxylation of the H-3,5-DCPCA precursor. These discrete 3,5-dichloropyridinium (H-3,5-DCPy) molecules fill as the template in the gaps between two adjacent layers of uranyl–organic network and interact with the layers by halogen bonding and hydrogen bonding to make a 3D framework. As shown in Figure , the distance of 3.585(8) Å between the chlorine atom (Cl(2)) of 3,5-dichloropyridinium and the closest Cl(1) atom in uranyl–organic network is shorter than the sum of the van der Waals radii, indicating the existence of halogen–halogen interaction, and this interaction can be attributed to type II based on the C–Cl···Cl angles of 163.05(65)° and 81.36(49)° (Table ). Meanwhile, the interaction is enhanced by hydrogen bonding of the C–H moiety to the axial O(3) atom of uranyl. Moreover, the N–H of 3,5-dichloropyridinium molecule hydrogen bonds to the adjacent layer from the opposite direction via the corner oxygen, O(1). In all, the 3,5-dichloropyridinium molecule cross-links the layered struture by a combination of halogen bonds and hydrogen bonds, and the resulting structure was characterized ().

elements.content: Compound 4 was fabricated from the bromine-substituted analogue of H-3,5-DCPCA, 3,5-dibromoisonicotinic acid (H-3,5-DBPCA, L4). Similar to 3, the crystal structure of 4 contains two components, which are the uranyl–organic moiety and 3,5-dibromopyridinium (). In the uranyl-containing moiety, the nitrogen atom in the pyridine ring of 3,5-DBPCA also coordinates to the uranyl center with a “NO4“ equatorial plane and combines with the carboxyl group to interconnect the infinite corner-sharing uranyl chain and build up a similar 2D network. The 2D network further interacts with 3,5-dibromopyridinium located within the layers by weak interactions (Figure ). Hydrogen bonds related to C(7)–H and N(2)–H of 3,5-dibromopyridinium link the neighboring layers from different directions, while halogen–halogen interactions are only found in one side, where each bromine atom of 3,5-dibromopyridinium interacts with two adjacent halogen-involving linkers bearing the Br–Br distances of 3.619(2) and 3.724(2) Å, respectively. Both the halogen–halogen interactions here can be assigned to type II, according to C–X···X angles, where one set is 168.17(29)° and 88.44(19)°, and the other is 117.94(29)° and 153.73(20)°.

elements.content: As depicted in quantum theory, the existence of the bond critical point (BCP) is one of the most important indicators for interatomic bonding interactions, and the electron density (ρ) properties at BCP afford a characterization of the interactions. In the inquiry for better insight into the nature of “X3” and “X6” synthons of halogen–halogen interaction found in these complexes, quantum theory of atoms in molecules (QTAIM) analysis was carried out in simplified molecular models of “X3” and “X6” at the M06-2X/RECP/6-311+G(d, p) level of theory. The BCPs referring to the X···X bonding interactions are clearly observed for “X3” and “X6” of compound 1 or 2 (see the , Figure S15). At the BCPs, the electron density (ρ), Laplacian of electron density (∇2ρ), the kinetic (G), and potential (V) energy density have been determined (Table ). For the X···X bonding with shorter interatomic lengths (R ij ) of 3.416/3.406 and 3.668/3.850 Å, the ρ, ∇2ρ, G, and V values (0.04 < ρ < 0.06 e/Å3, 0.4 < ∇2ρ < 0.8 e/Å5, 9.2 < G < 18.1 kJ/mol/Bohr3, −14.2 < V < 6.3 kJ/mol/Bohr3) are in the range of weak hydrogen bonds. In contrast, the ρ values for other X···X bonds are between 0.01 and 0.04 e/Å3, corresponding to van der Waals interactions, although they seem to be out of the suggested range of 0.03–0.06 e/Å3 in the Cl3 synthon reported by Espinosa and co-workers. The same results can be obtained from the ∇2ρ, G, and V values. Besides, the contour maps of ∇2ρ on the “X3” and “X6” synthon planes are displayed in . The regions between the halogen atom centers exhibit charge depletion (∇2ρ > 0), indicating the feature of close-shell interaction for the halogen–halogen bonding. It should be noted that X···X bonds with longer distances exhibit lower ρ, ∇2ρ, G, and V values and weaker interactions, and vice versa. Hence, those interactions of “X3” and “X6” synthons associated with inserted H-2,6-DCPCA or H-2,6-DBPCA fall in a weaker type of interactions as shown by their low ρ and ∇2ρ values. This result is in accordance with our former speculation that the “X3” and “X6” synthons belong to secondary interactions resulting from the driving forces of primary hydrogen bonds. On the other side, we should note that the halogen interactions associated with inserted isonicotinic acid for “X6” synthons are stronger than those in “X3” synthons (referring to No. 2 and 3 in “X3”, Table ). Moreover, the magnitudes of these parameters for the Br···Br bonding are found to be higher than those for the Cl···Cl bonding, which affords another proof of stronger interaction of the bromine bonding.

Quantum Chemical Calculation and Quantum Theory of Atoms in Molecules (QTAIM) Analysis of "X3" and "X6" Synthons

As depicted in quantum theory, the existence of the bond critical point (BCP) is one of the most important indicators for interatomic bonding interactions, and the electron density (ρ) properties at BCP afford a characterization of the interactions. In the inquiry for better insight into the nature of "X3" and "X6" synthons of halogen-halogen interaction found in these complexes, quantum theory of atoms in molecules (QTAIM) analysis was carried out in simplified molecular models of "X3" and "X6" at the M06-2X/RECP/6-311+G(d, p) level of theory. The BCPs referring to the X⋅⋅⋅X bonding interactions are clearly observed for "X3" and "X6" of compound 1 or 2 (see the , Figure S15). At the BCPs, the electron density (ρ), Laplacian of electron density (∇2ρ), the kinetic (G), and potential (V) energy density have been determined (Table ). For the X⋅⋅⋅X bonding with shorter interatomic lengths (R  ij ) of 3.416/3.406 and 3.668/3.850 Å, the ρ, ∇2ρ, G, and V values (0.04 < ρ < 0.06 e/Å3, 0.4 < ∇2ρ < 0.8 e/Å5, 9.2 < G < 18.1 kJ/mol/Bohr3, -14.2 < V < 6.3 kJ/mol/Bohr3) are in the range of weak hydrogen bonds. In contrast, the ρ values for other X⋅⋅⋅X bonds are between 0.01 and 0.04 e/Å3, corresponding to van der Waals interactions, although they seem to be out of the suggested range of 0.03-0.06 e/Å3 in the Cl3 synthon reported by Espinosa and co-workers. The same results can be obtained from the ∇2ρ, G, and V values. Besides, the contour maps of ∇2ρ on the "X3" and "X6" synthon planes are displayed in . The regions between the halogen atom centers exhibit charge depletion (∇2ρ > 0), indicating the feature of close-shell interaction for the halogen-halogen bonding. It should be noted that X⋅⋅⋅X bonds with longer distances exhibit lower ρ, ∇2ρ, G, and V values and weaker interactions, and vice versa. Hence, those interactions of "X3" and "X6" synthons associated with inserted H-2,6-DCPCA or H-2,6-DBPCA fall in a weaker type of interactions as shown by their low ρ and ∇2ρ values. This result is in accordance with our former speculation that the "X3" and "X6" synthons belong to secondary interactions resulting from the driving forces of primary hydrogen bonds. On the other side, we should note that the halogen interactions associated with inserted isonicotinic acid for "X6" synthons are stronger than those in "X3" synthons (referring to No. 2 and 3 in "X3", Table ). Moreover, the magnitudes of these parameters for the Br⋅⋅⋅Br bonding are found to be higher than those for the Cl⋅⋅⋅Cl bonding, which affords another proof of stronger interaction of the bromine bonding.

The reduced density gradient (RDG) method was also used to detect and visualize noncovalent interactions. The RDG isosurfaces (Figure ) depict clearly that weak interactions exist between the adjacent halogen atoms in “X3” and “X6” synthons, which are in agreement with the QTAIM analysis. Moreover, the plot of the RDG versus the electron density multiplied by the sign of the second Hessian eigenvalue (sign(λ2)ρ) further proves the existence of noncovalent interactions in these fragments as indicated by the spikes in the low-density and low-gradient region ().

elements.content: As demonstrated above, the multifunctional H-2,6-DCPCA or H-2,6-DBPCA molecules have weaved out a new type of unique uranyl supramolecular framework by simultaneous halogen bonds and hydrogen bonds, as well as “X3” and “X6” secondary halogen–halogen interactions, where halogen atoms, nitrogen atoms, and carboxyl groups make their own contributions. On one side, structural differences between the supramolular frameworks of 1 and 2 and uranyl compound of 4-halobenzoic acids suggest that the introduction of nitrogen atoms enhances the capability to form hydrogen bonds and induces a dramatic change on the crystal structure. On the other side, the effect of halogen groups on the construction of supramolecular frameworks has also been assessed through the comparison with the uranyl complexes from the isonicotinic acid analogues.
elements.clean_text:
Discussion

As demonstrated above, the multifunctional H-2,6-DCPCA or H-2,6-DBPCA molecules have weaved out a new type of unique uranyl supramolecular framework by simultaneous halogen bonds and hydrogen bonds, as well as "X3" and "X6" secondary halogen-halogen interactions, where halogen atoms, nitrogen atoms, and carboxyl groups make their own contributions. On one side, structural differences between the supramolular frameworks of 1 and 2 and uranyl compound of 4-halobenzoic acids suggest that the introduction of nitrogen atoms enhances the capability to form hydrogen bonds and induces a dramatic change on the crystal structure. On the other side, the effect of halogen groups on the construction of supramolecular frameworks has also been assessed through the comparison with the uranyl complexes from the isonicotinic acid analogues.

elements.content: We first compare the supramolular frameworks of 1 and 2 with U-PCA, a uranyl compound from pyridine-4-carboxylic acid (HPCA) without halogen substitution under similar hydrothermal conditions. Though a hydrogen bonded 3D structure was also achieved, the coordination pattern of ligand and packing pattern in U-PCA are different to 1. The structure differences between 1 and U-PCA indicate the halogen substitution entirely change the coordinating mode of the isonicotinic acid and the bonding interactions of the uranyl compound. Besides, when the analogues with only one chlorine substitute, L1′ and L1″, which show their high similarity to the molecular structure of L1, are employed (), both of the corresponding uranyl compounds 1′ and 1″ undergo hydrolysis of C–Cl bond to C–OH under similar hydrothermal conditions. The attempts to avoid hydrolysis by adjusting pH in a wider range, lowering the hydrothermal reaction temperature, or shortening the reaction time turned out to be unsuccessful. We found that the uranium-containing crystals being able to be characterized cannot be obtained until the occurrence of hydrolysis under the current reaction conditions. This may be related to the inherent nature of asymmetrical halogen-substituted isonicotinate precursors. In terms of differences between the ligands, this unexpected result indicates that the symmetrical structure of HDCPCA can stabilize the pyridinyl ring, while the asymmetrical analogues with one monochlorine tend to hydrolyze under hydrothermal conditions.
elements.clean_text: We first compare the supramolular frameworks of 1 and 2 with U-PCA, a uranyl compound from pyridine-4-carboxylic acid (HPCA) without halogen substitution under similar hydrothermal conditions. Though a hydrogen bonded 3D structure was also achieved, the coordination pattern of ligand and packing pattern in U-PCA are different to 1. The structure differences between 1 and U-PCA indicate the halogen substitution entirely change the coordinating mode of the isonicotinic acid and the bonding interactions of the uranyl compound. Besides, when the analogues with only one chlorine substitute, L1' and L1", which show their high similarity to the molecular structure of L1, are employed (), both of the corresponding uranyl compounds 1' and 1" undergo hydrolysis of C-Cl bond to C-OH under similar hydrothermal conditions. The attempts to avoid hydrolysis by adjusting pH in a wider range, lowering the hydrothermal reaction temperature, or shortening the reaction time turned out to be unsuccessful. We found that the uranium-containing crystals being able to be characterized cannot be obtained until the occurrence of hydrolysis under the current reaction conditions. This may be related to the inherent nature of asymmetrical halogen-substituted isonicotinate precursors. In terms of differences between the ligands, this unexpected result indicates that the symmetrical structure of HDCPCA can stabilize the pyridinyl ring, while the asymmetrical analogues with one monochlorine tend to hydrolyze under hydrothermal conditions.

elements.content: Further variation of dihalogen substitution in L1 and L2 from 2,6-positions to 3,5-positions gives the symmetric L3 and L4 molecules, which transform to uranyl compounds 3 and 4. As expected, symmetrical dihalogen-substituted structure stabilizes the C–X bonds themselves under mild hydrothermal conditions. Meanwhile, we found that the halogen substitution at 3,5-positions also leads to some other changes: it releases the space around the nitrogen atom at 1-position and enforces the configuration of carboyl group at 4-position perpendicular to the pyridine ring (), resulting in dramatical changes on its coordination beheavior and thermal stability as shown in the crystal structure of 3 and 4. All of these changes combine to create another type of halogen bonded and hydrogen bonded 3D uranyl–organic framework with 3,5-dihalogenpyridinium formed in situ as cross-linking agents of 2D layered networks. It is interesting to note that both of compounds 3 and 4 bear a space group of Ibca belonging to the orthorhombic systems, which are of high symmetry for a uranyl MOFs. Detailed analysis of the crystal structures reveals that the orthorhombic symmetry is related to the unique coordination pattern and intercalation stacking mode, where the former factor offers a 2-fold rotation axis along the b direction, and the latter offers another two 2-fold rotation axis along the a and c directions. Hence, the origin of this interesting high symmetry can be attributed to the special halogen substitution of isonicotinate for the organic precursors of L3 and L4.

elements.content: In all, synergistic introduction of different bonding moieties (halogen atoms for halogen bonding, and nitrogen atom and carboxylate group for hydrogen bonding) into multifunctional halogen-substituted isonicotinate enhances the bonding capacity of the resulting secondary building units by weak interactions, leading to the first case of 3D uranyl–organic supramolecular frameworks. Meanwhile, halogen substitution has a dramatical effect on the construction of supramolecular frameworks, and different strcutrues could be achieved by variation of halogen substitution.
elements.clean_text: In all, synergistic introduction of different bonding moieties (halogen atoms for halogen bonding, and nitrogen atom and carboxylate group for hydrogen bonding) into multifunctional halogen-substituted isonicotinate enhances the bonding capacity of the resulting secondary building units by weak interactions, leading to the first case of 3D uranyl-organic supramolecular frameworks. Meanwhile, halogen substitution has a dramatical effect on the construction of supramolecular frameworks, and different strcutrues could be achieved by variation of halogen substitution.

elements.content: The wide participation of “soft” weak interactions in multicomponent supramolecular frameworks 1 and 2 affords them more flexibility. Heat treatment of 1 or 2 in mild conditions (160 °C for 2 h) results in amorphous products (Figure a,c). Thermogravimetric analysis (Figure b,d) indicates only a change of losing water during this process. It can be speculated that the loss of lattice water might disrupt the hydrogen bonding networks and subsequently lead to the collapse of the crystal structure. Similar structural transformation is observed when treating 1 or 2 with ethanol. As expected, when the solids obtained after treating with heating or ethanol were redissolved into warm water followed by slow evaporation, the original form of 1 or 2 can be recovered, which is confirmed by single crystal X-ray diffraction analysis. This interesting recovery suggests that “soft” weak interaction within the uranyl–organic supramolecular framework enables it structural flexibility and dynamics, in spite of just a simple transformation related to lattice water.
elements.clean_text:
Dehydration and Recovery Based on Weak Interaction in 1 and 2 

The wide participation of "soft" weak interactions in multicomponent supramolecular frameworks 1 and 2 affords them more flexibility. Heat treatment of 1 or 2 in mild conditions (160 °C for 2 h) results in amorphous products (Figure a,c). Thermogravimetric analysis (Figure b,d) indicates only a change of losing water during this process. It can be speculated that the loss of lattice water might disrupt the hydrogen bonding networks and subsequently lead to the collapse of the crystal structure. Similar structural transformation is observed when treating 1 or 2 with ethanol. As expected, when the solids obtained after treating with heating or ethanol were redissolved into warm water followed by slow evaporation, the original form of 1 or 2 can be recovered, which is confirmed by single crystal X-ray diffraction analysis. This interesting recovery suggests that "soft" weak interaction within the uranyl-organic supramolecular framework enables it structural flexibility and dynamics, in spite of just a simple transformation related to lattice water.

elements.content: We have described assemblies of the first case of halogen bonded 3D uranyl-organic supramolecular frameworks with regular nanoscale channels by a cooperation of halogen–halogen interactions and hydrogen bonds as well as secondary “X3” and “X6” halogen–halogen interactions. Our synthetic approach employs halogen-substituted isonicotinic acids with multidentate bonding sites for coordination of uranyl center and construction of weak interaction-based network. The unprecedented “X6” synthon found here, especially for “Br6”, represents a new pattern of halogen–halogen interaction, and QTAIM analysis of “X3” and “X6” indicates their feature of secondary interaction. Another type of halogen bonded and hydrogen bonded 3D uranyl–organic framework with 3,5-dihalogenpyridinium formed in situ as cross-linking agents of 2D layered networks has been acquired via the variation of halogen substitution. In addition, reversible structure transformation of a 3D uranyl–organic supramolecular framework, which is available through the loss and regain of water involved in hydrogen bonding networks, enables its structural dynamics. Therefore, aside from extending this synergetic strategy to other multifunctional ligands, we are also exploring the potential applications of the supramoleular compounds in the fields of smart sensors, ion channels, and porous materials.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

We have described assemblies of the first case of halogen bonded 3D uranyl-organic supramolecular frameworks with regular nanoscale channels by a cooperation of halogen-halogen interactions and hydrogen bonds as well as secondary "X3" and "X6" halogen-halogen interactions. Our synthetic approach employs halogen-substituted isonicotinic acids with multidentate bonding sites for coordination of uranyl center and construction of weak interaction-based network. The unprecedented "X6" synthon found here, especially for "Br6", represents a new pattern of halogen-halogen interaction, and QTAIM analysis of "X3" and "X6" indicates their feature of secondary interaction. Another type of halogen bonded and hydrogen bonded 3D uranyl-organic framework with 3,5-dihalogenpyridinium formed in situ as cross-linking agents of 2D layered networks has been acquired via the variation of halogen substitution. In addition, reversible structure transformation of a 3D uranyl-organic supramolecular framework, which is available through the loss and regain of water involved in hydrogen bonding networks, enables its structural dynamics. Therefore, aside from extending this synergetic strategy to other multifunctional ligands, we are also exploring the potential applications of the supramoleular compounds in the fields of smart sensors, ion channels, and porous materials.

cln_elements.content: The compounds 1–4 described herein were synthesized hydrothermally as the forms of yellow-green or yellow crystals under autogenous pressure by using a Teflon-lined stainless-steel bomb from a mixture of uranyl nitrate hexahydrate and isonicotinic acid derivatives (L1–L4) with ammonium hydroxide. A typical synthesis precedure is as follows: UO2(NO3)2­·6H2O (200 μL, 0.1 mmol) were added to a suspension of isonicotinic acid precucusor (0.2 mmol) in water (1 mL) in a stainless-steel bomb. After treating with ammonium hydroxide (10 μL), the mixture was sealed, kept at 150 °C for 48 h, and cooled to room temperature to give yellow-green prism-like crystals, which were suitable for X-ray single crystal diffraction. The crystals were then filtered off, washed with water, and dried at room temperature (RT).
cln_elements.clean_text:
Synthesis

The compounds 1-4 described herein were synthesized hydrothermally as the forms of yellow-green or yellow crystals under autogenous pressure by using a Teflon-lined stainless-steel bomb from a mixture of uranyl nitrate hexahydrate and isonicotinic acid derivatives (L1-L4) with ammonium hydroxide. A typical synthesis precedure is as follows: UO2(NO3)2⋅6H2O (200 μL, 0.1 mmol) were added to a suspension of isonicotinic acid precucusor (0.2 mmol) in water (1 mL) in a stainless-steel bomb. After treating with ammonium hydroxide (10 μL), the mixture was sealed, kept at 150 °C for 48 h, and cooled to room temperature to give yellow-green prism-like crystals, which were suitable for X-ray single crystal diffraction. The crystals were then filtered off, washed with water, and dried at room temperature (RT).

cln_elements.clean_text: 1  Molecular Structures of Halogen-Substituted Isonicotinic Acids

cln_elements.content: Asymmetric unit of 1 containing three components and coordination sphere of dimeric uranium unit.
cln_elements.clean_text: 1  Asymmetric unit of 1 containing three components and coordination sphere of dimeric uranium unit.

cln_elements.content: An extended one-dimensional chain linked by ditopic Cl–Cl interactions of type I (a) and three-dimensional uranyl–organic supramolecular framework with regular nanoscale channels (b).
cln_elements.clean_text: 2  An extended one-dimensional chain linked by ditopic Cl-Cl interactions of type I (a) and three-dimensional uranyl-organic supramolecular framework with regular nanoscale channels (b).

cln_elements.content: Local stacking model of 1 with H-2,6-DCPCA molecules (bolded) filling in a typical cavity around four adjacent uranyl dimers (top), and hydrogen-bond networks of H-2,6-DCPCA facing down (bottom).
cln_elements.clean_text: 3  Local stacking model of 1 with H-2,6-DCPCA molecules (bolded) filling in a typical cavity around four adjacent uranyl dimers (top), and hydrogen-bond networks of H-2,6-DCPCA facing down (bottom).

cln_elements.content: Asymmetric triangular “Cl3” synthon and centrosymmetric hexagonal cyclic “Cl6” synthon originated from inserted H-2,6-DCPCA molecules in two adjacent layers (a) and in one layer (b) of 1D halogen–halogen bonded chains. For (a), the motifs in blue and pink colors represent different layers of 1D chains.
cln_elements.clean_text: 4  Asymmetric triangular "Cl3" synthon and centrosymmetric hexagonal cyclic "Cl6" synthon originated from inserted H-2,6-DCPCA molecules in two adjacent layers (a) and in one layer (b) of 1D halogen-halogen bonded chains. For (a), the motifs in blue and pink colors represent different layers of 1D chains.

cln_elements.content: Asymmetric unit and coordination sphere of the dimeric uranium unit of 2 (a) and the 1D extended chain (b).
cln_elements.clean_text: 5  Asymmetric unit and coordination sphere of the dimeric uranium unit of 2 (a) and the 1D extended chain (b).

cln_elements.content: Top: 3D uranyl–organic supramolecular framework of 2 (a) and a local stacking model with H-2,6-DBPCA molecules (bolded) filling in a typical cavity around four adjacent uranyl dimers (b). Bottom: hydrogen-bond networks of H-2,6-DBPCA facing down (c), and the “Br3” and hexagonal cyclic “Br6” synthon in one layer (d).
cln_elements.clean_text: 6  Top: 3D uranyl-organic supramolecular framework of 2 (a) and a local stacking model with H-2,6-DBPCA molecules (bolded) filling in a typical cavity around four adjacent uranyl dimers (b). Bottom: hydrogen-bond networks of H-2,6-DBPCA facing down (c), and the "Br3" and hexagonal cyclic "Br6" synthon in one layer (d).

cln_elements.content: Two discrete components involving in 3 (a), coordination sphere of the uranium unit (b), and 2D layered network constructed by the connection of the bidentate 3,5-DCPCA linkers (c).
cln_elements.clean_text: 7  Two discrete components involving in 3 (a), coordination sphere of the uranium unit (b), and 2D layered network constructed by the connection of the bidentate 3,5-DCPCA linkers (c).
